text1: "Alternative" and "complementary" medicine is as profit-driven as traditional Western medicine.
text2: Something that is profit-driven is likely to be more effective given that there is the incentive of profit.

text1: Profit driven corporations have an incentive to create medicines and procedures that are effective.
text2: Western medicine is dominated by profit driven corporations.

text1: Alternative medicine can have health hazards.
text2: Alternative treatment encompasses the wisdom of entire civilizations overlooked by traditional medicine.

text1: A vegan society would have environmental advantages.
text2: Veganism may cause people to be more complacent about their environmental choices, thereby reducing the likelihood they will make other important environmental decisions.

text1: A vegan society would have environmental advantages.
text2: Livestock farming can benefit the environment.

text1: A vegan society would have environmental advantages.
text2: People's eating habits are not the most important issue that should be addressed to save the environment.

text1: A vegan society offers the most sustainable way to manage resources.
text2: Producing certain vegan foods requires more water than livestock.

text1: A vegan society offers the most sustainable way to manage resources.
text2: Increased demand for vegan superfoods has encouraged producers to adopt production methods that are bad for the environment.

text1: Vegan agriculture requires less land, and treats what land it does use better.
text2: The farming techniques needed to increase crop production in a vegan world would damage the environment.

text1: Since natural environments are often destroyed to make space for pasture, a vegan world would reduce deforestation.
text2: Soya cultivation in Argentina and Brazil has been linked to extensive deforestation.

text1: Since natural environments are often destroyed to make space for pasture, a vegan world would reduce deforestation.
text2: Growing the appropriate caloric amount of vegan crops to supplant meat would require more arable land.

text1: Soil degradation could be reversed through vegan means, such as biochar, compost, no-till farming, biocyclic humus soil, and crop rotation.
text2: Continuous cropping destroys soil structure and causes erosion, while pasture animals can reduce soil degradation (p. 1, p. 1344).

text1: Soil degradation could be reversed through vegan means, such as biochar, compost, no-till farming, biocyclic humus soil, and crop rotation.
text2: Biocyclic humus is expensive and opposed by large agricultural companies, making its widespread adoption unlikely.

text1: Overgrazing can cause soil degradation as well as a host of other environmental issues.
text2: Continuous cropping destroys soil structure and causes erosion, while pasture animals can reduce soil degradation (p. 1, p. 1344).

text1: In a vegan world, since humans would not be producing crop for animal feed, crop production is likely to decrease and - with it - the use of damaging techniques, such as monocropping.
text2: Monocrop agriculture, which may be needed to meet the demand for vegan products, has been environmentally detrimental.

text1: Crop rotation is more sustainable for the environment and results in greater yields (p. 405). This method could be used to increase vegan crop production.
text2: The farming techniques needed to increase crop production in a vegan world would damage the environment.

text1: Compared to animal agriculture, veganism wastes less food.
text2: Food wastage would still occur in a vegan society, meaning world hunger may still exist.

text1: If all humans were vegan, plant crops currently grown for farm animal consumption could feed humans instead.
text2: Humans already produce more food than they eat. There is no need for societies to become vegan to allow all humans to have enough to eat: a better means of distributing food is needed.

text1: If all humans were vegan, plant crops currently grown for farm animal consumption could feed humans instead.
text2: World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitical inequalities and conflicts (p. 14).

text1: More than 800 million people worldwide do not have enough to eat. Livestock grain could feed them all if used for human consumption instead.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Feeding livestock low-quality feed grains may result in malnutrition.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Inedible or spoiled plant co-products could be utilised as fertilizers in place of manure or chemicals instead of being consumed by animals.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Future technologies may be able to convert previously inedible biological matter into food that is digestible for humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Grain-fed animals eat the same foods as humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Hunger has always existed, both in times of geopolitical stability and conflict.
text2: World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitical inequalities and conflicts (p. 14).

text1: The conversion of crops into meat is highly inefficient compared to the direct consumption of plant matter (p. 8164).
text2: Not all arable land in the world is suitable for crop production, and many of the by-products of human food production can only be eaten by ruminants.

text1: Feeding livestock low-quality feed grains may result in malnutrition.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Inedible or spoiled plant co-products could be utilised as fertilizers in place of manure or chemicals instead of being consumed by animals.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Future technologies may be able to convert previously inedible biological matter into food that is digestible for humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Grain-fed animals eat the same foods as humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Arable land that is unsuitable for crop production could be reserved as natural ecosystems.
text2: Not all arable land in the world is suitable for crop production, and many of the by-products of human food production can only be eaten by ruminants.

text1: The waste of animal produce has a greater detrimental environmental effect than the waste of vegan foods.
text2: Food wastage would still occur in a vegan society, meaning world hunger may still exist.

text1: Only a small amount of vegan foods put significant pressure on water resources. Vegans can consume vegan foods that do not use as much water (p. 1577).
text2: Producing certain vegan foods requires more water than livestock.

text1: Far more water resources are used for animal agriculture than crop agriculture.
text2: Producing certain vegan foods requires more water than livestock.

text1: A vegan society would be the most effective at combating climate change.
text2: As industries increasingly transition to sustainable fuel sources, the reduction of global emissions may be accomplished by means other than the elimination of the meat industry.

text1: A vegan society would be the most effective at combating climate change.
text2: Cultivated meat is a more environmentally sustainable method of creating conventional food.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: The research on veganism's impact on greenhouse gases is inconsistent.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: When considered per calorie, vegetarian diets may actually produce more greenhouse gas emissions than those of omnivores.

text1: Vegan diets are associated with reduced greenhouse gas emissions and a much lower carbon footprint (p. 1).
text2: Vegan diets are often reliant on highly processed meat and dairy alternatives, meaning that most are no more environmentally beneficial (in terms of their carbon footprint) than an ovo-lacto-vegetarian diet (pp. 6-7).

text1: Animal agriculture is a major contributor to global warming. A global move to a vegan diet could reduce food-related greenhouse gas emissions (which make up 37% of human-activity emissions) by two-thirds by 2050 (p. 4146).
text2: A vegan society would be more dependent on imported foods, making transport emissions even worse.

text1: Methane from cows and other livestock constitutes 44% of human-produced methane in the atmosphere.
text2: Converting livestock methane into biogas could reduce the methane emissions from animal agriculture.

text1: Most food-related greenhouse gas emissions occur during production, with final transport to retail only contributing 4% of the total emissions (p. 3508).
text2: Many vegan foods travel more miles than meat, contributing to a higher overall carbon footprint.

text1: CO₂ emissions from increased transport would still likely pale in comparison to those produced in animal agriculture.
text2: A vegan society would be more dependent on imported foods, making transport emissions even worse.

text1: Plants grown for food absorb CO₂.
text2: The net absorption of CO₂ by plants is low enough that it does not contribute much to greenhouse gas reduction.

text1: Kelp and other seaweeds are high protein food stuffs that absorb CO₂ more effectively than trees.
text2: Kelp and seaweed, which help absorb greenhouse gases in the ocean, are often farmed using unsustainable methods such as dredging.

text1: Global adherence to a vegan diet would contribute to carbon sequestration.
text2: Developing more properly-managed grazing spaces for cattle by regenerating grasslands may help capture more carbon than the animals produce.

text1: Carbon sinks will eventually reach their limit (p. 2708), and grasslands supporting grass-fed cattle only store 20-60% of the greenhouse gases produced by the grazing cattle.
text2: Developing more properly-managed grazing spaces for cattle by regenerating grasslands may help capture more carbon than the animals produce.

text1: The problem of climate change is urgent. Governments must cut emissions in all areas as quickly as possible to have a realistic chance of limiting it. Therefore, even if green energy is adopted, humans should still go vegan.
text2: As industries increasingly transition to sustainable fuel sources, the reduction of global emissions may be accomplished by means other than the elimination of the meat industry.

text1: Research suggests that - without considerable changes to its production methods and infrastructure - cultivated beef would not have a significantly reduced carbon footprint when compared to beef from cattle (p. 8)
text2: Cultivated meat is a more environmentally sustainable method of creating conventional food.

text1: A vegan society would create the least pollution.
text2: If all societies became vegan, the use of chemical fertilizers would dramatically increase due to the loss of animal fertilizer. This switch is not a sustainable or eco-friendly option.

text1: A vegan society would create the least pollution.
text2: Vegan foods and products often contain - or are packaged in - non-biodegradable materials.

text1: Pollution caused by grazing damages river systems.
text2: Rotational grazing can help reduce damage to river systems without abandoning animal agriculture entirely (p. 2118).

text1: Many waterways are polluted with farm animal faeces, causing the water to contain levels of nitrogen and phosphorus that are unsafe for human consumption (p. vii).
text2: Regenerative animal agriculture can benefit waterways and oceans.

text1: Human faeces is vegan and could be a replacement for animal manure.
text2: Manure is sustainable, while fertilizer mining is not.

text1: Technological advances, such as fertilizer rationing software, can reduce fertilizer use.
text2: If all societies became vegan, the use of chemical fertilizers would dramatically increase due to the loss of animal fertilizer. This switch is not a sustainable or eco-friendly option.

text1: Chemical fertilizers are safer for human health than manure.
text2: If all societies became vegan, the use of chemical fertilizers would dramatically increase due to the loss of animal fertilizer. This switch is not a sustainable or eco-friendly option.

text1: Chemical fertilizers are safer for human health than manure.
text2: Chemical fertilizers may increase people's risk of cancer.

text1: Many plastic-free stores are vegan or vegetarian.
text2: Vegan foods and products often contain - or are packaged in - non-biodegradable materials.

text1: People may become environmentally complacent even if they are not vegan.
text2: Veganism may cause people to be more complacent about their environmental choices, thereby reducing the likelihood they will make other important environmental decisions.

text1: Allowing land unsuitable for agriculture to be returned to wild habitats would have a much greater positive environmental impact than using it for grazing.
text2: Vegetation-rich areas that are unsuitable for crop agriculture can be used for grazing, reducing the need for other, environmentally damaging animal feed sources.

text1: Animal flocks could still be held for their environmental benefits without harming or exploiting them.
text2: Livestock farming can benefit the environment.

text1: Animal flocks could still be held for their environmental benefits without harming or exploiting them.
text2: Some vegans consider any kind of human control or ownership of animals to be unethical. Using animal flocks, then, could be considered non-vegan.

text1: Pasture animals can damage biodiversity.
text2: Livestock farming can benefit the environment.

text1: Pasture animals can damage biodiversity.
text2: Traditional pasturing has benefited some native species and helped to preserve their habitats. Stopping it would destroy a centuries-old equilibrium and endanger those species.

text1: Pasture animals can damage biodiversity.
text2: In many instances, livestock grazing is crucial for biodiversity.

text1: Livestock produce 14.5% of all CO₂ equivalent greenhouse gases (p. xii), while all transportation produces 14% of all CO₂ equivalent greenhouse gases. Becoming vegan would have an environmental effect similar to stopping all travel.
text2: Travel has a significant negative impact on the environment.

text1: Currently, there are few, if any, alternatives to extremely polluting forms of long-distance travel.
text2: Travel has a significant negative impact on the environment.

text1: It is possible to immediately decide to be vegan. Other environmental decisions, such as changing to renewable energy, are not always available in the short term.
text2: People's eating habits are not the most important issue that should be addressed to save the environment.

text1: Given the severity of the climate emergency, people ought to do as much as possible to limit their carbon footprint. There is, therefore, nothing contradictory in both becoming vegan and fighting against other sources of climate change.
text2: People's eating habits are not the most important issue that should be addressed to save the environment.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.
text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: Veganism reduces both human and animal suffering.
text2: Universal veganism would exploit and kill more animals than it would save.

text1: The meat industry significantly harms its workers and nearby communities.
text2: Many crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as health problems and low pay (p. 6).

text1: The meat industry significantly harms its workers and nearby communities.
text2: The meat industry employs half a million people in the US and has brought employment to previously depressed areas (p. 1).

text1: Slaughterhouse employees report that their work severely affects their emotional and mental health, which also often impacts their families and communities.
text2: There are a number of other professions that are seen also as mentally stressful and traumatic, yet society does not consider these necessary to eradicate.

text1: Safety standards in the meat industry are poor.
text2: Worker safety standards differ between countries and can be improved regardless of whether all humans are vegan.

text1: If everyone were vegan, global agricultural land usage would decrease by 75%. This would result in far fewer farmers, likely improving working conditions.
text2: Many crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as health problems and low pay (p. 6).

text1: Ethical issues with vegan production chains result from broader exploitative production systems, not veganism itself.
text2: Many crops are picked by migrant farmers that face sexual, verbal, and physical abuse, as well as health problems and low pay (p. 6).

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: While it may seem cruel, academic and laboratory research often requires animal testing and experimentation in order to create products that save the lives of humans and animals alike.

text1: Animals raised for human use are often treated cruelly.
text2: There are more ethical routes to obtain animal products that emphasize animal welfare and dignity.

text1: In the dairy industry, some calves are removed from their mothers at birth or killed if it is too expensive to rear them.
text2: Long-term studies found no evidence that calves suffer behaviourally or developmentally when separated from their mothers (p. 5550).

text1: Not all forms of cruelty result in inferior quality meat.
text2: Meat producers usually want animals to die quickly to prevent pain-associated chemicals from forming, which may spoil the meat (p. 1).

text1: Crueler methods of livestock management allow farms to increase the quantity they produce at a lower cost. Even if some consumers resent lower quality, cruel farms will likely be more profitable.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text1: Many slaughterhouses have been caught flouting animal cruelty laws, resulting in animals experiencing immense suffering before their deaths.
text2: It is not in the meat industry's interest to treat animals cruelly, as mistreating cattle results in poorer quality meat (p. 6).

text1: There are an increasing number of alternatives to animal testing (p. 223). Funding and research into these methods would likely be increased in a vegan society, making them more feasible.
text2: While it may seem cruel, academic and laboratory research often requires animal testing and experimentation in order to create products that save the lives of humans and animals alike.

text1: While purchasing from small-scale producers may be more ethical, most consumers prioritize the cost and ease of meat over the ethics of its production.
text2: Purchasing from small-scale producers of animal products is more ethical than purchasing from industrial farms.

text1: Small-scale meat production would be unable to satisfy global demand for meat.
text2: Purchasing from small-scale producers of animal products is more ethical than purchasing from industrial farms.

text1: While some products exist, the mass availability of affordable cultured meat is still a long way off.
text2: Scientific advancements, such as lab-grown meat, make it possible for people to eat meat without animal farming and slaughter.

text1: Humane farming still necessitates slaughter or mutilation. As such, it does not meaningfully reduce the suffering inflicted upon animals.
text2: There are more ethical routes to obtain animal products that emphasize animal welfare and dignity.

text1: Humane farming still necessitates slaughter or mutilation. As such, it does not meaningfully reduce the suffering inflicted upon animals.
text2: Hunting, if done ethically, can give animals a more peaceful death than they would have experienced at the hands of a non-human predator (p. 183).

text1: Humane farming still necessitates slaughter or mutilation. As such, it does not meaningfully reduce the suffering inflicted upon animals.
text2: Organic farming places a strong emphasis on animal welfare and requires that animals are kept healthy and in humane conditions.

text1: Halal and kosher slaughter methods may actually be crueler than secular farming methods, as they do not stun the animals before killing them, causing more suffering.
text2: The slaughter of animals using kosher or halal rules makes the process as quick and painless as possible (p. 31).

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.
text2: There are more ethical routes to obtain animal products that emphasize animal welfare and dignity.

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.
text2: There are many companies that produce certified humane animal products.

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.
text2: Halal meat - seen by Muslims as the only ethical way to kill an animal - is widely practised throughout the world. Therefore, it is feasible to use such methods on a large scale.

text1: Ethical farming practices are rarely used, meaning most people do not have access to - or cannot afford - ethically produced meat.
text2: Many countries have begun mandating that animals be stunned before slaughter, making the process significantly less painful for the animal.

text1: A vegan society would cause singificantly less harm to wildlife.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: In a vegan world, fewer species would be at risk of extinction.
text2: Properly managed animal farming can benefit biodiversity.

text1: Industrial agriculture can dangerously decrease animal populations.
text2: Sustainable livestock farming is not contributing to significant decreases in animal populations. Decreasing animal populations is a problem specific to industrial livestock farming.

text1: The argument that grazing animals can help fight climate change has been challenged by scientists who argue that any environmental benefits are offset by the volume of greenhouse gases emitted by the livestock.
text2: If lost herds are not replaced with ruminant animals, deserts will be created, causing far more environmental damage than animal greenhouse gases.

text1: Beef agriculture is the most significant cause of tropical deforestation, which accounts for around 10% of global warming emissions.
text2: If lost herds are not replaced with ruminant animals, deserts will be created, causing far more environmental damage than animal greenhouse gases.

text1: Industrial farming is a major cause of the loss of biodiversity.
text2: Properly managed animal farming can benefit biodiversity.

text1: Animal agriculture severely harms wildlife as farmers tend to kill wildlife in order to protect their livestock (p. 1).
text2: Wild pigs are destructive, costing the US an estimated $2.5 billion yearly in damages and control costs. It is therefore appropriate for farmers to kill these animals.

text1: Many invasive species have been introduced to new territories on vegan crops.
text2: Human-introduced species have historically devastated local wildlife populations across the world.

text1: Feral animals are proof that domesticated animals - including livestock - can successfully return to the wild.
text2: Not only would releasing livestock into the wild be unethical in terms of its impact on wildlife, but it would be unethical in terms of the harms it would inflict on livestock, who have not been bred to survive in the wild.

text1: Effective vegan methods to control animal populations exist.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: Effective vegan methods to control animal populations exist.
text2: Hunting can be a more effective method to control overpopulation and invasive animal species, and can rebalance ecosystems..

text1: Neutering can reduce population sizes without killing any animals.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text1: Anaesthesia has been used when neutering wild cats. This suggests it could be used when neutering farm animals, even if it is not currently.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text1: Inflicting some amount of pain and distress on animals is better than killing them.
text2: The castration of farm animals is routinely performed surgically and without anaesthesia. Any en-masse neutering for population control would likely be performed in the same way, causing significant suffering.

text1: Many species of wild animals have been and continue to be hunted to extinction or near extinction (p. R551), including by farmers.
text2: Hunting can be a more effective method to control overpopulation and invasive animal species, and can rebalance ecosystems..

text1: Natural selection will correct for species' overpopulation eventually.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: Natural selection will correct for species' overpopulation eventually.
text2: Natural selection does not guarantee a favorable outcome for native species and may lead to the extinction of many species.

text1: It's unlikely that livestock would be released into the wild. The livestock would probably still be slaughtered. However, breeding would likely decrease according to demand, reversing the production growth.
text2: If all humans go vegan, entire ecosystems could be disrupted by the overpopulation of livestock if they were released into the wild.

text1: Most of the animals killed by humans for food - such as cows, pigs, and chickens - do not usually kill humans or each other.
text2: Humans are just another type of animal. Therefore, we are only as morally obliged not to kill or dominate other species as they are morally obliged not to kill or dominate each other.

text1: Most of the animals killed by humans for food - such as cows, pigs, and chickens - do not usually kill humans or each other.
text2: Most predators are not eaten by their prey. The fact that gazelles do not eat lions is not a reason to stop lions from eating gazelles.

text1: The fact that an action is natural does not imply that it is moral.
text2: It is natural for humans to subordinate animals for their needs.

text1: It is rare for humans to desire to kill animals, and their physiology suggests they are not designed to do so.
text2: It is natural for humans to subordinate animals for their needs.

text1: It is rare for humans to desire to kill animals, and their physiology suggests they are not designed to do so.
text2: There is evidence that humans have innate hunting traits and possess a natural hunting instinct.

text1: Human bodies are largely not able to kill animals on their own, implying it is not natural to do so. Humans often need tools to kill animals, unlike other predators.
text2: Many non-human animals use tools to kill their prey.

text1: Infants do not possess the rational faculties of adults, yet are considered to have rights.
text2: Since animals do not possess free will to the same extent as humans, they cannot have the same rights (p. 538).

text1: A lack of free will may mean that animals do not have positive rights, but they could still have negative rights, for which free will is not necessary.
text2: Since animals do not possess free will to the same extent as humans, they cannot have the same rights (p. 538).

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: The fact that humans have greater rational faculties than animals makes them entitled to do what they wish with animals.

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: From a biological and psychological perspective, the distinction between humans and animals is small.
text2: Complex cognitive differences in how humans think and experience emotions mean that it is natural for us to perceive ourselves as superior to other animals.

text1: Just like humans, animals desire to live.
text2: An animal's desire to live does not imply its right to live. Under the concept of survival of the fittest, everything wants to survive, but only the fittest will.

text1: A number of animals have passed the mirror test, proving that they can recognise themselves as individuals.
text2: The mirror test is a very unreliable test of self-awareness.

text1: Even if morals only apply to human actions, they still constrain what humans are morally allowed to do to animals.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: It is immoral to do harm to a person who is asleep or in a temporary coma as they are still moral agents. The same applies to animals.
text2: To be a moral actor, one must be capable of making moral decisions. Animals do not have this ability.

text1: Many mammals can experience similar mental conditions to humans, including depression, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, and anxiety disorders.
text2: Complex cognitive differences in how humans think and experience emotions mean that it is natural for us to perceive ourselves as superior to other animals.

text1: Animals should be considered to have innate rights, which are violated by non-vegan practices. Therefore, eating animals relies on speciesist conceptions of animals.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: Animals should be considered to have innate rights, which are violated by non-vegan practices. Therefore, eating animals relies on speciesist conceptions of animals.
text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text1: All living things, even bacteria, respond to stimulus (p. 558). Yet, not all living things are sentient in a morally relevant sense.
text2: That plants react to damage is evidence that these organisms do not want to die.

text1: The consumption of fruit by other organisms is an essential part of many plants' reproduction systems, so eating fruit is compatible with these plants’ rights.
text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text1: Plants lack the nervous system and pain receptors necessary to experience pain, and its accompanying emotions, in the way that sentient beings do (p. 883).
text2: Plants have many of the qualities generally used to justify granting rights to humans and animals. By this logic, they too should have individual rights.

text1: Plants lack the nervous system and pain receptors necessary to experience pain, and its accompanying emotions, in the way that sentient beings do (p. 883).
text2: Experts in the field of plant neurobiology can not agree on whether or not plants possess the equivalent of a brain and nervous system.

text1: The fact that animals can suffer makes them worthy of moral concern and implies that humans ought to not consume them.
text2: Humans have the right to treat animals in such a way as meets their needs. As such, they have few obligations to minimize the suffering of animals.

text1: The fact that animals can suffer makes them worthy of moral concern and implies that humans ought to not consume them.
text2: A being’s ability to suffer does not entitle them to specific protections or rights.

text1: The experience of pain and pleasure is the most important moral consideration there is. Since animals can experience them, it is wrong to inflict unnecessary suffering on them.
text2: A being’s ability to suffer does not entitle them to specific protections or rights.

text1: The lack of representation of people of color is a general problem of these countries. It is not caused by, but rather reflected in, veganism.
text2: Veganism is typically depicted using white, affluent individuals, despite its non-white roots.

text1: Veganism is primarily a first-world trend and is most popular in Western countries and cities.
text2: Veganism is typically depicted using white, affluent individuals, despite its non-white roots.

text1: Comparisons between human and animal suffering effectively challenge the mismatch between our moral considerations of humans and animals.
text2: Advertisements for veganism have made problematic comparisons between the suffering of animals and the suffering experienced by minority communities.

text1: In a world where everyone is vegan, there would be no need for advertisements for veganism.
text2: Advertisements for veganism have made problematic comparisons between the suffering of animals and the suffering experienced by minority communities.

text1: Many vegan companies, like Beyond Meat and Miyoko's, have proactively taken anti-racist stances and tried to increase awareness of structural racism.
text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: More widespread veganism would likely lead to more inclusive dietary advice.
text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: More widespread veganism would likely lead to more inclusive dietary advice.
text2: Despite the growing popularity of global veganism, white men continue to represent the majority of subjects in clinical trials and other forms of health research, including dietary research (p. 1).

text1: Many meat products are guilty of environmental racism, whereby industrial livestock production disproportionally pollutes Black, Latinx and Indigenous areas.
text2: Many vegan practices and portrayals of veganism are racist. These would become more harmful and widespread if everyone were vegan.

text1: Bees would pollinate plants regardless of whether they are industrially grown by farmers or exist in the wild. Therefore, the role of pollination in the agriculture industry does not constitute exploitation.
text2: The agriculture industry uses insects like bees to grow crops (p. 3). Universal veganism would require the greater exploitation of such insects.

text1: Since a number of prominent vegan organizations have been very critical of palm oil, many vegans avoid using it.
text2: Farmers have historically taken land away from wildlife to farm crops, threatening some species. This is especially true of palm oil cultivation.

text1: Raising animals also requires the production of plants, meaning the same suffering will occur. At least, with veganism, an additional set of animals do not suffer.
text2: Universal veganism would exploit and kill more animals than it would save.

text1: The accidental deaths resulting from growing and harvesting plants are morally different from the intentional deaths caused by slaughtering animals.
text2: Universal veganism would exploit and kill more animals than it would save.

text1: Methods like indoor or hydroponic farming and cultured meat involve far less animal suffering.
text2: Universal veganism would exploit and kill more animals than it would save.

text1: Although top allergens are also the top vegan protein sources (soy and wheat), most vegan companies offer products made from peas and almonds.
text2: The most common trigger foods for some medical conditions - such as celiac disease, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (p. 547), and G6PD deficiency - are often staples of a vegan diet. People who have these conditions may find veganism difficult.

text1: People can successfully live with IBS while following a vegan diet.
text2: The most common trigger foods for some medical conditions - such as celiac disease, irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (p. 547), and G6PD deficiency - are often staples of a vegan diet. People who have these conditions may find veganism difficult.

text1: People with hemochromatosis can benefit greatly from a vegan diet due to plants' less absorbable nonheme iron (p. 66).
text2: Plant sources of iron only contain nonheme forms of iron, while meat sources contain both heme and nonheme. Having both sources makes iron more available for absorption and use in the body.

text1: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition has argued that vegans generally have adequate iron intake and do not experience anemia at a higher rate than others (p. 1629S).
text2: Some medications and medical conditions can create predispositions for anaemia, which can cause blindness (p. 1). As vegan diets can be low in iron, veganism can be dangerous for people with these conditions.

text1: Many older people experience heart problems, which are often exacerbated by eating large amounts of red or processed meat.
text2: Many older people already struggle with health complications. Malnutrition, which is more commonly seen in vegan diets, could make these health conditions worse.

text1: A study found no link between orthorexia nervosa and veganism or vegetarianism, instead citing ethical reasons as the motivation behind these diets (p. 1).
text2: Attempting to adhere to a strict vegan diet can lead to orthorexia, an obsession with eating a "pure" diet.

text1: If everyone were vegan, veganism would no longer be seen as restrictive. This would diminish the attractiveness of veganism to people with restrictive eating disorders.
text2: Veganism can be adopted as a way to legitimise continued restrictive eating behaviour (pp. 5-6).

text1: The belief that veganism exacerbates eating disorders is a stereotype which is often perpetuated by disorder treatment centers.
text2: The restrictive nature of a vegan diet may exacerbate eating disorders or trigger those who suffer from them.

text1: There is no evidence of a direct causal link between veganism and eating disorders.
text2: The restrictive nature of a vegan diet may exacerbate eating disorders or trigger those who suffer from them.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.
text2: Some medical conditions and medication that affect nutrition can prevent a person from going vegan.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.
text2: Some vegans, like those who follow a raw food vegan diet, do not obtain the nutrients fortified in processed vegan foods.

text1: Many processed vegan foods are fortified with nutrients typically found in animal products.
text2: Individuals suffering from ineffective biosynthesis conditions - such as retinol deficiency and Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome - cannot utlise the nutrients in fortified vegan products and need to consume some animal products (p. 1).

text1: There are very few people for whom some version of a vegan diet is not advisable.
text2: Some medical conditions and medication that affect nutrition can prevent a person from going vegan.

text1: Children of vegetarian mothers do not have a higher incidence of brain development issues than the children of omnivores (p. 1).
text2: Unless carefully balanced, a vegan diet can impair brain development in children.

text1: Mothers can breastfeed their children for years, and breast milk from vegan mothers has comparable nutritional value to that of non-vegans.
text2: Deficiencies common in vegan diets increase the risk of growth and developmental problems in children and babies.

text1: Mothers can breastfeed their children for years, and breast milk from vegan mothers has comparable nutritional value to that of non-vegans.
text2: Some vegans do not believe that breastfeeding is vegan. Avoiding breastfeeding is nutritionally sub-optimal, as breastmilk is a complete nutrient source.

text1: Avoiding consensually sourced human breastmilk is a controversial form of veganism. A more moderate approach could be pursued instead.
text2: Some vegans do not believe that breastfeeding is vegan. Avoiding breastfeeding is nutritionally sub-optimal, as breastmilk is a complete nutrient source.

text1: Children are often pressured into eating meat by their parents, cultural conditioning, and advertisements (p. 6).
text2: Since a strict vegan diet may not meet the nutritional requirements of children and adolescents (p. 6), it should not be forced on children until they are old enough to choose it for themselves.

text1: Children are often pressured into eating meat by their parents, cultural conditioning, and advertisements (p. 6).
text2: Since babies and young children cannot decide what they eat, all food (including plant-based food) is essentially forced upon them.

text1: Parents should have the right to raise a child in accordance with their own values. When they are old enough, children can make their own decisions.
text2: Since a strict vegan diet may not meet the nutritional requirements of children and adolescents (p. 6), it should not be forced on children until they are old enough to choose it for themselves.

text1: Parents should have the right to raise a child in accordance with their own values. When they are old enough, children can make their own decisions.
text2: If a parent thinks that stealing is acceptable, that does not mean they should be allowed to raise their child to be a thief.

text1: Disabled vegan advocates have argued that special accommodations can be made for disabled people where necessary.
text2: Many people with common disabilities may find veganism more challenging due to the time, energy, and fine motor skills required to prepare many vegan foods.

text1: Vegan diets can be adaptable and suitable for many kinds of complex or specific dietary needs. For example, there is mounting evidence that a plant-based diet can benefit athletes despite their complex nutritional needs.
text2: A vegan diet is not well-suited for vulnerable individuals or people with lifestyles requiring specialised nutrition, who may be unable to remove animal products from their diet.

text1: Vegan diets can be adaptable and suitable for many kinds of complex or specific dietary needs. For example, there is mounting evidence that a plant-based diet can benefit athletes despite their complex nutritional needs.
text2: Iron and zinc are two of the most common nutrient deficiencies in athletes' diets, and are nutrients which are largely unavailable in vegan diets.

text1: It is currently virtually impossible for vegans to entirely avoid animal products. As such, people should be considered vegan if they do as much as possible to remove animal products from their lives, even if they have to use them on occasion.
text2: A vegan diet is not well-suited for vulnerable individuals or people with lifestyles requiring specialised nutrition, who may be unable to remove animal products from their diet.

text1: A study detailing individuals with a low normal or deficient B12 range showed that there is no significant difference the between those who eat meat and those who do not (pp. 514-515).
text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text1: The B12 found in meat is often supplemented into the animal's food rather than being an innate component of it.
text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text1: Many vegan foods are fortified with bacteria-derived vitamin B12. B12 in fortified foods has greater bioavailability than that found in animal products.
text2: Those following a vegan diet are at an increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency.

text1: Omega-3 and DHA are both readily available from a number of vegan food products and supplements.
text2: Vegans are more deficient than meat-eaters in the omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA (p. 333).

text1: EPA and DHA omega-3 fatty acids could be created from converting plant-based ALA and SDA in the body, albeit at a slow rate.
text2: Vegans are more deficient than meat-eaters in the omega-3 fatty acids EPA and DHA (p. 333).

text1: EPA and DHA omega-3 fatty acids could be created from converting plant-based ALA and SDA in the body, albeit at a slow rate.
text2: Conversion of the plant-sourced omega-3 (ALA) to animal-sourced omega-3s (EPA and DHA) can be very slow, suggesting that vegans will struggle to obtain enough omega-3 fats.

text1: Table salt is iodized in many countries because iodine deficiency is recognized as a public health concern among many people, not just vegans.
text2: Iodine is not consistently available from vegan foods.

text1: High amounts of iodine are naturally present in seaweed, which can be cultivated in a variety of coastline environments.
text2: Iodine is not consistently available from vegan foods.

text1: If adequate and correct supplementation can fill in the gaps of a limited or incomplete diet, it can be considered complete and healthy (p. 1).
text2: It is often necessary for a vegan diet to include food supplements, as it lacks specific essential nutrients contained in a healthy diet.

text1: If adequate and correct supplementation can fill in the gaps of a limited or incomplete diet, it can be considered complete and healthy (p. 1).
text2: Supplements do not replace the need for a varied diet.

text1: If adequate and correct supplementation can fill in the gaps of a limited or incomplete diet, it can be considered complete and healthy (p. 1).
text2: The nutrients in supplements may not be absorbed during digestion as effectively as those in whole foods, making them less optimal to fill the gaps left by animal products.

text1: Research suggests that no significant vitamin or mineral deficiencies affect the vegan population compared to non-vegans (p. 2). This is largely because most core vitamins can be easily obtained on a vegan diet.
text2: It is often necessary for a vegan diet to include food supplements, as it lacks specific essential nutrients contained in a healthy diet.

text1: Research suggests that no significant vitamin or mineral deficiencies affect the vegan population compared to non-vegans (p. 2). This is largely because most core vitamins can be easily obtained on a vegan diet.
text2: Some vegan foods contain anti-nutrients. These can prevent people from absorbing nutrients they would typically get from meat.

text1: Anti-nutrients from plant-based foods are not a concern for human health and may actually help lower the absorption of proteins and phosphates (p. 19), high levels of which can lead to kidney damage.
text2: Some vegan foods contain anti-nutrients. These can prevent people from absorbing nutrients they would typically get from meat.

text1: Some nutrients and vitamins are actually easier to obtain with a vegan diet, compared to a meat-eating one.
text2: It is often necessary for a vegan diet to include food supplements, as it lacks specific essential nutrients contained in a healthy diet.

text1: Some nutrients and vitamins are actually easier to obtain with a vegan diet, compared to a meat-eating one.
text2: Even if some vegan foods have higher amounts of certain vitamins and nutrients, it may nonetheless be easier to access all the nutrients one needs with an omnivorous diet.

text1: Anti-nutrients from plant-based foods are not a concern for human health and may actually help lower the absorption of proteins and phosphates (p. 19), high levels of which can lead to kidney damage.
text2: Protein-rich vegan foods can contain anti-nutrients like lectins that lower the bioavailability of the protein's amino acids (p. 120).

text1: The above study examined the effects of uncooked soybeans, peas, and fava beans on pigs. We cannot assume that the same effect will be present in humans when the foods are cooked (p. 4).
text2: Protein-rich vegan foods can contain anti-nutrients like lectins that lower the bioavailability of the protein's amino acids (p. 120).

text1: Some vegan foods, like quinoa, can provide vegans with a complete protein source.
text2: Many animal products provide a complete protein source, whereas most vegan foods do not. As a result, obtaining enough high quality, bioavailable protein through a vegan diet can be challenging.

text1: Concerns about protein consumption in developed countries are exaggerated. Most vegans already get plenty of protein in their diets.
text2: Many animal products provide a complete protein source, whereas most vegan foods do not. As a result, obtaining enough high quality, bioavailable protein through a vegan diet can be challenging.

text1: Concerns about protein consumption in developed countries are exaggerated. Most vegans already get plenty of protein in their diets.
text2: Protein consumption among older people is too low in some countries (p. 1).

text1: While many Americans consume sufficient amounts of protein, the processed meat they consume to obtain it is often high in sugar and fat. Getting protein primarily from plant sources may help tackle this issue.
text2: Many animal products provide a complete protein source, whereas most vegan foods do not. As a result, obtaining enough high quality, bioavailable protein through a vegan diet can be challenging.

text1: Many expert organizations agree that a vegan diet can be as healthy as an omnivorous one (p. 1).
text2: Veganism is unhealthy.

text1: Many expert organizations agree that a vegan diet can be as healthy as an omnivorous one (p. 1).
text2: Nutritionists at the University of Oxford have highlighted that scientists do not know enough about the effects of vegan diets to make clear judgements about their healthiness.

text1: Many expert organizations agree that a vegan diet can be as healthy as an omnivorous one (p. 1).
text2: While USDA dietary guidelines state that a healthy nutritional profile can be gained from a vegetarian diet (p. 33), they do not make the same claim for a vegan diet.

text1: Many expert organizations agree that a vegan diet can be as healthy as an omnivorous one (p. 1).
text2: The WHO has warned that meat substitutes can lead to negative health impacts, despite many people considering them to be part of a healthy vegan diet.

text1: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics (AND) has supported a well-planned vegan diet as nutritionally healthy and adequate since 2009 (p. 1266).
text2: While it may back veganism as a healthy option, the AND's lack of diversity among its members and within its research suggests it may not support marginalised communities to follow such a lifestyle.

text1: Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of diseases.
text2: Veganism is unhealthy.

text1: Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of diseases.
text2: Wildlife may still be a source of food-borne illnesses in vegan food.

text1: Veganism can help prevent the emergence and spread of diseases.
text2: The most effective way to prevent communicable diseases in humans is through the practice of good hygiene and food safety education (p. 754).

text1: The raising and selling of livestock as meat spreads food-borne and zoonotic diseases (such as E. coli, toxoplasmosis, and swine flu). A vegan society reduces the potential that pathogens will transfer between animals and humans.
text2: Plant-based agriculture can also spread diseases.

text1: The raising and selling of livestock as meat spreads food-borne and zoonotic diseases (such as E. coli, toxoplasmosis, and swine flu). A vegan society reduces the potential that pathogens will transfer between animals and humans.
text2: As vegans are increasingly growing their own food, they may be at a greater risk of contracting toxoplasmosis from cat faeces in gardens and vegetable plots.

text1: Some of the worst disease outbreaks in human history have been linked to poor conditions in meat markets and factory farms. Universal veganism would reduce the likelihood of these outbreaks.
text2: Cholera, one of the deadliest diseases in history, is associated with poor human hygiene and sewage disposal, not animals.

text1: Animal diseases are more likely to pass to humans than diseases in plant crops due to genetic and biochemical similarities.
text2: Plant-based agriculture can also spread diseases.

text1: Food-borne illnesses in crops may still come from livestock (pp. 15-16).
text2: Plant-based agriculture can also spread diseases.

text1: Industrial animal farming promotes the growth of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.
text2: Some farm chickens are not given any antibiotics.

text1: A vegan diet may help reduce the risk of certain lifestyle diseases.
text2: Dairy consumption may help address malnutrition.

text1: A vegan diet may help reduce the risk of certain lifestyle diseases.
text2: The research linking animal products to health issues can be contradictory.

text1: A vegan diet may help reduce the risk of certain lifestyle diseases.
text2: Many vegan alternatives are more processed than their meat and dairy counterparts, and tend to contain unhealthy additives that can contribute to lifestyle diseases.

text1: Vegan populations are, on average, less likely to suffer from obesity (p. 1267), a major risk factor for many diseases and health problems (p. 5).
text2: Some people gain weight on a vegan diet.

text1: A vegan diet can help prevent heart disease, which is the leading cause of human death worldwide.
text2: Vegans can still eat some of the unhealthy aspects of an omnivore's diet (such as saturated fat, sugar, and salt). Healthy diets need to reduce all foods that increase the risk of heart disease, not just animal-based ones.

text1: Since it lowers the level dietary cholesterol, a vegan diet significantly reduces the risk of ischemic heart disease compared to an omnivorous diet (p. 3640).
text2: Healthy non-vegan diets can be low in cholesterol.

text1: Since it lowers the level dietary cholesterol, a vegan diet significantly reduces the risk of ischemic heart disease compared to an omnivorous diet (p. 3640).
text2: Many vegan meat alternatives have high amounts of sodium, which can increase the risk of heart disease and stroke.

text1: The consumption of dairy and red meat has been linked to an increased risk of developing cancer.
text2: The link between dairy and breast cancer has been challenged.

text1: The consumption of dairy and red meat has been linked to an increased risk of developing cancer.
text2: Drinking low-fat milk may reduce one's risk of getting colorectal cancer (p. 1330).

text1: While commercials often suggest that consuming milk is the best way to obtain clacium, many vegan foods contain it much higher quantities.
text2: Dairy consumption may help address malnutrition.

text1: Many genetically modified crops are designed to be resistant to pesticides, resulting in farmers using them much more liberally. Vegans who consume these crops may be at greater risk of exposure to pesticide residues.
text2: Only consuming organic crops reduces exposure to pesticides.

text1: It may be difficult or impossible to sustain the world's population on organic crops alone.
text2: Only consuming organic crops reduces exposure to pesticides.

text1: Non-vegans also eat vegan food, so contamination of vegan food would still be a significant problem in a non-vegan society.
text2: Wildlife may still be a source of food-borne illnesses in vegan food.

text1: Global veganism could help eradicate world hunger, the greatest health crisis facing humankind in the long term (p. 1).
text2: Veganism is unhealthy.

text1: Global veganism could help eradicate world hunger, the greatest health crisis facing humankind in the long term (p. 1).
text2: Universal veganism would worsen existing food distribution and access problems.

text1: Global veganism could help eradicate world hunger, the greatest health crisis facing humankind in the long term (p. 1).
text2: Compared to animal products, vegan foods have low bioavailability. Vegans may be unable to replace the nutrients lost through common diarrheal diseases, making veganism an inappropriate diet choice for people in developing countries.

text1: Vegan foods can be more readily and cheaply preserved for longer.
text2: Freezing, canning, and drying meat increases its shelf life.

text1: If all humans were vegan, plant crops currently grown for farm animal consumption could feed humans instead.
text2: Humans already produce more food than they eat. There is no need for societies to become vegan to allow all humans to have enough to eat: a better means of distributing food is needed.

text1: If all humans were vegan, plant crops currently grown for farm animal consumption could feed humans instead.
text2: World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitical inequalities and conflicts (p. 14).

text1: More than 800 million people worldwide do not have enough to eat. Livestock grain could feed them all if used for human consumption instead.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Feeding livestock low-quality feed grains may result in malnutrition.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Inedible or spoiled plant co-products could be utilised as fertilizers in place of manure or chemicals instead of being consumed by animals.
text2: Food grown for humans that does not meet food standards (such as those imposed by the USDA) is usually discarded. A sensible alternative would be to repurpose this discarded food as animal feed.

text1: Future technologies may be able to convert previously inedible biological matter into food that is digestible for humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Grain-fed animals eat the same foods as humans.
text2: 86% of livestock feed is inedible for humans (p. 1). Animals are therefore helping humans recycle crop co-products and food waste (p. 10).

text1: Hunger has always existed, both in times of geopolitical stability and conflict.
text2: World hunger is not currently caused by a lack of food but by geopolitical inequalities and conflicts (p. 14).

text1: Global veganism would reduce food and health inequality.
text2: Even if all humans were vegan, it does not follow that the vegan diets of the rich and poor would be equal in quality, variety, or reliability.

text1: Food deserts are not doomed to be food deserts forever. As technology changes, new solutions may be found to make fresh food more readily available in these areas.
text2: Universal veganism would worsen existing food distribution and access problems.

text1: Arbitrarily discarded fruit and vegetables, such as the billions of pounds of "ugly" produce, could help feed large numbers of people worldwide.
text2: Universal veganism would worsen existing food distribution and access problems.

text1: Many staple crops can be grown in highly diverse environments. For example, some starch crops can be grown in most climates, which may help combat food deserts.
text2: Universal veganism would worsen existing food distribution and access problems.

text1: Climate change will make maintaining many of these traditional diets impossible anyway. Altering these traditions to be more eco-friendly is the best way to preserve them.
text2: If all humans were vegan, many traditional non-vegan dishes would be lost.

text1: Many cultures may be able to find ways to cook vegan alternatives in the same traditional ways, continuing to honor their historical practices.
text2: Traditional culinary practices have value and ought to be protected.

text1: Non-Western cultures already eat fewer animal products than Western ones.
text2: Meat and dairy are important to some cultures.

text1: Non-Western cultures already eat fewer animal products than Western ones.
text2: While non-Western cultures traditionally consume fewer animal products, the global desire to align with Western values means this trend is already changing substantially.

text1: Some religious practices, such as Jainism, align particularly well with veganism since followers actively avoid killing animals, even in extreme survival situations (p. 1502).
text2: Veganism conflicts with some people's religious beliefs and practices.

text1: Hinduism advocates for non-violence, which is incompatible with the harms committed by the meat industry.
text2: Veganism conflicts with some people's religious beliefs and practices.

text1: Many passages in the Qur'an stress kindness, mercy, and compassion to animals.
text2: Veganism conflicts with some people's religious beliefs and practices.

text1: Many religions already offer alternatives to contentious items in their ceremonies. Given that this flexibility already exists, vegan substitutions should also be made.
text2: Veganism conflicts with some people's religious beliefs and practices.

text1: Just because the focus of humanism is on human welfare, it does not follow that humans are assumed to be more important than animals.
text2: Humanism declares humans as the most valuable species, while veganism explicitly condemns that as "speciesism" or "carnism".

text1: Humanism is a rational philosophy driven by compassion. Due to the environmental and health benefits of veganism, becoming vegan is a compassionate thing to do for others and oneself.
text2: Veganism contradicts humanism.

text1: Some humanist publications have endorsed veganism.
text2: Veganism contradicts humanism.

text1: Some men consider their vegan diet to be an important part of a progressive masculinity that embraces feminist and intersectional veganism (p. 1).
text2: Some men feel that veganism undermines their masculinity and, therefore, may feel embarassed by attempting to reduce their meat consumption (p. 2).

text1: Some prominent male combat sport combatants, like Nate Diaz, are publicly vegan. Combat sports are popular among men and emphasise traditional models of masculinity.
text2: Some men feel that veganism undermines their masculinity and, therefore, may feel embarassed by attempting to reduce their meat consumption (p. 2).

text1: Vegans exist in all political and ideological circles, implying that veganism is compatible with most views.
text2: Veganism conflicts with many peoples' politics and ideologies.

text1: Vegans exist in all political and ideological circles, implying that veganism is compatible with most views.
text2: The fact that some people within all political circles are vegan does not undercut the importance that meat-eating plays in the political views of many.

text1: Much of the political resistance towards veganism comes from misrepresentation of vegans through pro-meat lobbies or the media.
text2: Veganism conflicts with many peoples' politics and ideologies.

text1: Much of the political resistance towards veganism comes from misrepresentation of vegans through pro-meat lobbies or the media.
text2: Even if it is the case that some of the opposition to veganism is manufactured, given that these political actors have great power, anti-veganism has become a sincere view that should be respected.

text1: Cultures can preserve their practices without compromising them by making vegan substitutions.
text2: Veganism is incompatible with some religions, cultures, and ideologies.

text1: Cultures can preserve their practices without compromising them by making vegan substitutions.
text2: Many traditions require animal slaughter. These cannot be replicated with vegan alternatives.

text1: Traditions can and do change over time.
text2: Veganism is incompatible with some religions, cultures, and ideologies.

text1: Traditions can and do change over time.
text2: Forcing people to change their traditions often causes a significant backlash, which can make change even harder.

text1: Traditions can and do change over time.
text2: Meat-related traditions may be especially resistant to change, since many people view them as a part of their identity and attempts to change them as an infringement of their personal choice (p. 7).

text1: Many states have outlawed unethical cultural practices.
text2: The outlawing of cultural practices typically only applies to traditions that are universally accepted as unethical. Given that many people still feel comfortable eating meat, it is unlikely it will be outlawed.

text1: The current global growth in veganism is an indication that people are willing to make changes to their cultural or ideological views.
text2: There are five times as many ex-vegans as there are vegans. Almost two-thirds of them are not interested in re-adopting veganism.

text1: The current global growth in veganism is an indication that people are willing to make changes to their cultural or ideological views.
text2: The demand for meat is increasing around the world.

text1: In India, where there are millions of vegans, a large portion of society became vegetarian a long time ago (p. 1).
text2: Many Indians are vegetarian for religious reasons. It would be difficult to inspire the commitment needed for universal veganism in the modern secular and multicultural world.

text1: In India, where there are millions of vegans, a large portion of society became vegetarian a long time ago (p. 1).
text2: India has fewer vegetarians than is commonly believed.

text1: The demand for meat could be tied to the subsidization of meat products, resulting in them being cheaper than plant-based food. This would imply nothing about the popularity of meat.
text2: The demand for meat is increasing around the world.

text1: Many countries around the world have already reached peak meat consumption (p. 1).
text2: The demand for meat is increasing around the world.

text1: Veganism does not necessarily forbid pet ownership. There are many ways that people can keep pets while abiding by vegan principles.
text2: Humans gain many benefits from pet ownership and animal domestication. In a vegan world forbidding pets, these benefits would be lost.

text1: Veganism does not necessarily forbid pet ownership. There are many ways that people can keep pets while abiding by vegan principles.
text2: Pets do not consent to be owned by a human. Therefore, pet ownership cannot be vegan.

text1: Veganism does not necessarily forbid pet ownership. There are many ways that people can keep pets while abiding by vegan principles.
text2: Having pets necessitates holding animals in captivity.

text1: Vegan diet options are available for some carnivorous pets and domesticated animals.
text2: Some animals, like cats, cannot change to a vegan diet.

text1: Vegan diet options are available for some carnivorous pets and domesticated animals.
text2: It is not definitively known yet whether vegan diets are safe for pets.

text1: There are other ways of interacting with nature that do not require killing or exploiting animals, like visiting wildlife parks, hiking, or working at animal shelters.
text2: Interactions with animals bring people substantial happiness. However, many vegans believe these activities are not vegan and would deprive people of them.

text1: Humans primarily eat meat because they are conditioned to do so. Therefore, it is possible to change social norms towards vegan practices.
text2: Vegans miss out on enjoyable and culturally important foods and experiences, making veganism a difficult lifestyle to maintain.

text1: Humans primarily eat meat because they are conditioned to do so. Therefore, it is possible to change social norms towards vegan practices.
text2: Mutliple factors play into humans' social conditioning with regards to meat-eating, which makes this behaviour difficult to change (p. 4).

text1: Humans primarily eat meat because they are conditioned to do so. Therefore, it is possible to change social norms towards vegan practices.
text2: Norms surrounding meat-eating have existed for about 2.6 million years. As such, the conditioning toward meat-eating is highly entrenched and difficult to change.

text1: The enjoyment of food is often derived not just from its taste but also from the social aspects of preparing and eating it. People can have comparable experiences on a vegan diet.
text2: Vegans miss out on enjoyable and culturally important foods and experiences, making veganism a difficult lifestyle to maintain.

text1: The enjoyment of food is often derived not just from its taste but also from the social aspects of preparing and eating it. People can have comparable experiences on a vegan diet.
text2: Following a restrictive diet can make it harder to engage in social events, as eating in restaurants is more difficult.

text1: The enjoyment of food is often derived not just from its taste but also from the social aspects of preparing and eating it. People can have comparable experiences on a vegan diet.
text2: Many people prefer the taste of meat and dairy and would miss it were they to become vegan.

text1: Given that the social aspect of eating together is often what makes food culturally important, vegan food would not affect it.
text2: Often the process of procuring and cooking food is important to cultural food experiences (p. 1). These would be lost with universal veganism.

text1: Forms of vegan community cooking are possible and have been widely used.
text2: Often the process of procuring and cooking food is important to cultural food experiences (p. 1). These would be lost with universal veganism.

text1: More vegan options are available in most restaurants, and the number of vegan restaurants is increasing.
text2: Following a restrictive diet can make it harder to engage in social events, as eating in restaurants is more difficult.

text1: Difficulty maintaining a vegan diet from a social perspective does not mean that all of humanity should not turn vegan. In fact, it would erase the barrier between meat eaters and vegans as it is now.
text2: Following a restrictive diet can make it harder to engage in social events, as eating in restaurants is more difficult.

text1: Vegan substitutes are increasingly realistic, to the point that even professional chefs cannot distinguish them from actual meat. This suggests that such products are likely to satisfy meat cravings in vegans.
text2: Meat cravings are common among all people, including vegans.

text1: People's taste buds adjust to their diet, enabling them to stop craving specific foods after some time away from them.
text2: Many people prefer the taste of meat and dairy and would miss it were they to become vegan.

text1: People's taste buds adjust to their diet, enabling them to stop craving specific foods after some time away from them.
text2: Taste is not the only thing driving people's desires for specific foods. People can get cravings for meat due to their gut bacteria.

text1: As technology improves, synthetic meat substitutes will be more able to replicate the sensations of meat eating.
text2: Many people prefer the taste of meat and dairy and would miss it were they to become vegan.

text1: As technology improves, synthetic meat substitutes will be more able to replicate the sensations of meat eating.
text2: The diet and lifestyle of an animal have a significant effect on its flavor. This would not be easy to replicate in a laboratory.

text1: Meat creates toxic metabolites that have a stimulating effect that may cause people to become addicted and feel hungover.
text2: Many people prefer the taste of meat and dairy and would miss it were they to become vegan.

text1: Meat creates toxic metabolites that have a stimulating effect that may cause people to become addicted and feel hungover.
text2: Metabolites in meat products are often a result of processing or canning (pp. 20-21). It is not clear whether fresh meat poses the same risk.

text1: Storing food energy for winters is possible without livestock by using equipment such as granaries to protect crop harvests.
text2: Farmers often use animals to store energy for harsh winters or where the terrain does not allow intensive crop farming.

text1: Singapore has one of the highest global population densities, making it difficult to grow food. Even so, the city's inhabitants have found ways to grow crops, especially by using vertical farming.
text2: A vegan world would result in more poverty for those living in rural areas and nonarable environments (p. 9), many of whom depend on animal agriculture and products for their livelihoods (p. xx).

text1: Better planning for equitable food distribution would prevent demand spikes from harming others. This is, therefore, not a vegan-specific problem.
text2: High demand for vegan foods may hike prices for local populations that previously depended on them.

text1: A balanced vegan diet is generally cheaper than one that includes meat. This means that, in a vegan world, consumers may have more disposable income.
text2: A vegan society would be economically damaging for less privileged communities.

text1: A balanced vegan diet is generally cheaper than one that includes meat. This means that, in a vegan world, consumers may have more disposable income.
text2: Replacing all non-food animal products with vegan ones would be extremely expensive for consumers.

text1: A balanced vegan diet is generally cheaper than one that includes meat. This means that, in a vegan world, consumers may have more disposable income.
text2: Experimenting to find the right vegan diet can be expensive for individuals.

text1: A balanced vegan diet is generally cheaper than one that includes meat. This means that, in a vegan world, consumers may have more disposable income.
text2: The increased need for supplements on a vegan diet may also increase the cost of living healthily, making the diet less accessible.

text1: Grains and legumes make up most of a vegan diet's protein and calorie content. These are very inexpensive and are often available in bulk or can even be homegrown.
text2: In the US, fruits and vegetables are more expensive than meat when considered isocalorically (p. 647).

text1: While the technology is still in its infancy, it is possible to manipulate the genetics of bacteria to create products like milk and insulin (p. 1).
text2: There are sometimes hidden and unavoidable animal-based materials used within medical science.

text1: As technology advances, it is increasingly feasible for many products that people mistakenly assume are vegan to be made vegan without affecting their quality.
text2: Many commonly used products - which many people may assume are vegan - are made with, or contain, animal-derived materials. The cost of adapting such products to be fully vegan will inevitably be passed on to the customer.

text1: As a result of government subsidies, plant-based products are often more expensive than animal products. If the US$38 billion of subsidies currently allocated to meat went to fruit and vegetables, they would be cheaper.
text2: Replacing all non-food animal products with vegan ones would be extremely expensive for consumers.

text1: Diets need not be changed suddenly. Someone who wants to become vegan can gradually incorporate more vegan foods until they find a complete vegan diet they like.
text2: Experimenting to find the right vegan diet can be expensive for individuals.

text1: Poorer people are more likely to be vegan than richer ones.
text2: A vegan society would be economically damaging for less privileged communities.

text1: Poorer people are more likely to be vegan than richer ones.
text2: Dietary diversity is lowest among poorer populations. Given this, it is important that they are able to eat meat (p. 3911S).

text1: Most individuals that live in poverty are currently eating a majority vegan diet because it is all they can afford.
text2: Poverty is also strongly linked to malnutrition, so it does not necessarily follow that veganism is better or more feasible for the world's poorest people.

text1: Around a third of the population of India, a country where the majority live in poverty, are vegetarian. This suggests that veganism can be an affordable diet for societies.
text2: The extremely poor in India tend to be malnourished on a vegan diet, as the food that is affordable does not give them adequate nutrients to survive.

text1: Many people become vegan for primarily environmental reasons. These people may be more inclined to purchase food grown locally, reducing food imports.
text2: Countries would depend more on food imports in a vegan world and thus be more vulnerable to global market volatility.

text1: Many people become vegan for primarily environmental reasons. These people may be more inclined to purchase food grown locally, reducing food imports.
